user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimerGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_TimerGetInfo(osal_id_t timer_id, OS_timer_prop_t *timer_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *           record;
    int32                          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t                 objtype;
    OS_object_token_t              token;
    OS_timecb_internal_record_t *  timecb;
    OS_timebase_internal_record_t *timebase;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timer_prop);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    memset(timer_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_timer_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, timer_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_timecb_table, token);
        timecb   = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timecb_table, token);
        timebase = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_timebase_table, timecb->timebase_token);

        strncpy(timer_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timer_prop->name) - 1);
        timer_prop->creator       = record->creator;
        timer_prop->interval_time = (uint32)timecb->interval_time;
        timer_prop->accuracy      = timebase->accuracy_usec;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_TimerGetInfo:
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
    uint32    start_time;
    uint32    interval_time;
    uint32    accuracy;
} OS_timer_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char              timer_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    uint32            flags;
    OS_object_token_t timebase_token;
    osal_id_t         prev_cb;
    osal_id_t         next_cb;
    uint32            backlog_resets;
    int32             wait_time;
    int32             interval_time;
    OS_ArgCallback_t  callback_ptr;
    void *            callback_arg;
} OS_timecb_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct
{
    char           timebase_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    OS_TimerSync_t external_sync;
    uint32         accuracy_usec;
    osal_id_t      first_cb;
    uint32         freerun_time;
    uint32         nominal_start_time;
    uint32         nominal_interval_time;
} OS_timebase_internal_record_t
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_timecb_table
...
OS_timecb_internal_record_t OS_timecb_table[OS_MAX_TIMERS]
...
extern OS_timebase_internal_record_t OS_timebase_table[OS_MAX_TIMEBASES]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
strncpy(timer_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timer_prop->name) - 1);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated: strncpy(timer_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(timer_prop->name) - 1) copies at most (OS_MAX_API_NAME - 1) bytes into timer_prop->name which has size OS_MAX_API_NAME. The source record->name_entry is defined with the same OS_MAX_API_NAME size in the provided structures, so the call will not read beyond the source buffer and will not write beyond the destination buffer. Furthermore the code previously zeroed the entire timer_prop (memset), which guarantees a terminating NUL byte even if strncpy copies exactly the given limit. A potential violation would occur only if record->name_entry were a smaller object (or a pointer to a shorter buffer) than sizeof(timer_prop->name) - 1 — in that hypothetical case strncpy could read beyond the source bounds.
